column1: 2014JGRE..119.1914F|2014|Regolith thickness over Sinus Iridum: Results from morphology and size-frequency distribution of small impact craters|Fa
column8: Junichi|Journal of Geophysical Research (Planets)|119|8|1914|High-resolution optical images returned from recent lunar missions provide a new chance for estimation of lunar regolith thickness using morphology and the size-frequency distribution of small impact craters. In this study
column9: regolith thickness over the Sinus Iridum region is estimated using Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter Camera (LROC) Narrow Angle Cameras (NACs) images. A revised relationship between crater geometry and regolith thickness is proposed based on old experimental data that takes into considering the effect of the illumination angle of the images. In total
column10: 227 high-resolution LROC NAC images are used
column12: 556 impact craters with diameters from 4.2 to 249.8 m are counted
column13: and their morphologies are identified. Our results show that 50% of the Sinus Iridum region has a regolith thickness between 5.1 and 10.7 m
column14: and the mean and median regolith thicknesses are 8.5 and 8.0 m
column15: respectively. There are substantial regional variations in the regolith thickness
column16: with its median value varying from 2.6 to 12.0 m for most regions. Local variations of regolith thickness are found to be correlated with the lunar surface age: the older the surface
column17: the greater the thickness. In addition
column18: sporadically distributed impact ejecta and crater rays are associated with relatively larger regolith thickness
column19: which might result from excavation and transport of materials during the formation of the secondaries of Copernican-aged craters. Our estimated regolith thickness can help with future analysis of Chang'E-3 lunar penetrating radar echoes and studies of the subsurface stratigraphic structure of the Moon.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/2013JE004604
